guide.conclusion:
As it is, this gravity-based application method requires a screen, separate from the wall, that can be positioned horizontally to sprinkle on the glass. I'm not at all convinced that my method for building the screen (nor for attaching it to the wall) is the best one. Improve it!

The final surface--glass beads embedded in latex house paint--is surprisingly robust. I was at first concerned that flexion of the screen would cause the beads to flake off. Fortunately, the latex paint retains plenty of flexibility, at least over the few weeks my prototypes have existed. I almost think you could go so far as applying it to a thin surface that actually rolls up.

Another pleasant surprise was that, at viewing distances, the surface treatment is remarkably tolerant of small imperfections, and does not require a very smooth texture. I believe it could even be applied directly to a textured wall, and the next step is to figure out a convenient process for doing so, thus eliminating the need for a separate screen altogether. Stay tuned!

guide.introduction: Here’s a method for applying a high-gain optical projection surface using common, inexpensive materials—specifically, flat white interior latex paint and glass sandblasting media. It began as a series of experiments to produce a DIY “screen paint” by directly mixing these two ingredients. Though failing in themselves, these tests led to the serendipitous discovery of this process.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Here’s a method for applying a high-gain optical projection surface using common, inexpensive materials—specifically, flat white interior latex paint and glass sandblasting media. It began as a series of experiments to produce a DIY “screen paint” by directly mixing these two ingredients. Though failing in themselves, these tests led to the serendipitous discovery of this process.

Relevant parts
  • Hardboard
  • Paint
  • Glass bead blasting media
  • 1x2" lumber (nominal), 8 foot section
  • Screws
  • Anchor
  • Wood screw
  • Unthreaded spacers
Tools
  • Countersink
  • Drill
  • Drill bit
  • Dustpan
  • Hand broom
  • Hot glue gun
  • Measuring tape
  • Miter box and saw
  • Paintbrush
  • Paint roller
  • Plastic drop cloth
  • Screwdriver
  • Tape
  • Tub

lines.text: I actually attached the frame timbers after applying the screen finish, so I had to install screws from back to front, being careful not to accidentally damage the finish on the screen side. lines.text: A plastic painter's drop cloth will be used to collect loose glass beads after the application of the screen surface.

lines.text: Spread the plastic in a clean area with a smooth floor.
lines.text_raw: Spread the plastic in a clean area with a smooth floor.

lines.text: Tape the edges of the sheet down.

lines.text: Set your screen panel down in the middle of the plastic sheet.
lines.text_raw: Set your screen panel down in the middle of the plastic sheet.

lines.text: Paint the edges of your screen surface first.  I used a 1" disposable foam brush.
lines.text_raw: Paint the edges of your screen surface first.  I used a 1" disposable foam brush.

lines.text: Apply a smooth, even coat of paint to the screen area using a roller.
lines.text_raw: Apply a smooth, even coat of paint to the screen area using a roller.

lines.text: Though I used a paint tray for the first coat, by the second coat I figured out it's easier to just pour the paint out of the can directly onto the screen, Jackson Pollock-style, and then smooth it out with the roller.

lines.text: Let the basecoat dry 24 hours.

lines.text: Pour out your supply of glass beads into a plastic tub.
lines.text_raw: Pour out your supply of glass beads into a plastic tub.

lines.text: A cheap plastic dustpan makes a convenient applicator for the sprinkling process.  With just a bit of practice, it's easy to get a fairly even sheet of falling beads.

lines.text: After 24 hours, apply a second coat of paint to the screen edges, as before.
lines.text_raw: After 24 hours, apply a second coat of paint to the screen edges, as before.

lines.text: Pour out about 1/2 quart of paint, directly from the can onto the screen, doing your best to distribute it evenly around the surface.
lines.text_raw: Pour out about 1/2 quart of paint, directly from the can onto the screen, doing your best to distribute it evenly around the surface.

lines.text: Roller the paint smooth.  You want a quick, even, fairly heavy coat.
lines.text_raw: Roller the paint smooth.  You want a quick, even, fairly heavy coat.

lines.text: Try to get a smooth coat, but don't fret too much, either now or later, about small surface imperfections.  The process is remarkably tolerant of these.
lines.text_raw: Try to get a smooth coat, but don't fret too much, either now or later, about small surface imperfections.  The process is remarkably tolerant of these.

lines.text: Immediately after applying the topcoat, while it's still wet, start sprinkling glass beads generously over the entire surface.
lines.text_raw: Immediately after applying the topcoat, while it's still wet, start sprinkling glass beads generously over the entire surface.

lines.text: Be careful not to miss any areas.  Once the paint is dry, the surface is very difficult to touch up, so be sure to get adequate coverage the first time 'round.
lines.text_raw: Be careful not to miss any areas.  Once the paint is dry, the surface is very difficult to touch up, so be sure to get adequate coverage the first time 'round.

lines.text: Don't be stingy with the beads; go ahead and apply them all. Excess will be collected later and it's better to use too much than too little.
lines.text_raw: Don't be stingy with the beads; go ahead and apply them all. Excess will be collected later and it's better to use too much than too little.

lines.text: Leave the beads undisturbed at least 24 hours for the paint to dry.
lines.text_raw: Leave the beads undisturbed at least 24 hours for the paint to dry.

lines.text: Once the paint has dried for 24 hours, brush off the excess glass beads using a plastic fiber brush.  I used the brush that came with my dustpan.
lines.text_raw: Once the paint has dried for 24 hours, brush off the excess glass beads using a plastic fiber brush.  I used the brush that came with my dustpan.

lines.text: The glass bead coating is actually quite robust.  It makes sense to start gently, but you will soon realize you don't have to baby it.
lines.text_raw: The glass bead coating is actually quite robust.  It makes sense to start gently, but you will soon realize you don't have to baby it.

lines.text: When most of the beads have been brushed away, lift the screen from one edge and give it a a few thumps on the backside to dislodge any remaining loose beads.
lines.text_raw: When most of the beads have been brushed away, lift the screen from one edge and give it a a few thumps on the backside to dislodge any remaining loose beads.

lines.text: Stand the screen upright and give it a final brushing.  Peel off any paint flash around the edge of the screen with your fingers.
lines.text_raw: Stand the screen upright and give it a final brushing.  Peel off any paint flash around the edge of the screen with your fingers.

lines.text: Gather up the tarp, from the edges, into a "sack," as shown.
lines.text_raw: Gather up the tarp, from the edges, into a "sack," as shown.

lines.text: Lift the sack into your plastic tub or tray.
lines.text_raw: Lift the sack into your plastic tub or tray.

lines.text: Release one edge of the tarp and slowly work it out from underneath the mass of recovered glass.
lines.text_raw: Release one edge of the tarp and slowly work it out from underneath the mass of recovered glass.

lines.text: I recovered almost two-thirds (16/25 lbs) of the beads I applied using this method.
lines.text_raw: I recovered almost two-thirds (16/25 lbs) of the beads I applied using this method.

lines.text: For my 48x96" screen, I positioned a row of four anchors eight inches down from the ceiling with 20" between them.  When the screen is centered on the anchors, that leaves 18" from each edge to the nearest anchor.
lines.text_raw: For my 48x96" screen, I positioned a row of four anchors eight inches down from the ceiling with 20" between them.  When the screen is centered on the anchors, that leaves 18" from each edge to the nearest anchor.

lines.text: I used screw-in metal drywall anchors rated to 40 lbs vertical load apiece.  These require no pre-drilling; just position them over your pencil mark and turn them in with a screwdriver.
lines.text_raw: I used screw-in metal drywall anchors rated to 40 lbs vertical load apiece.  These require no pre-drilling; just position them over your pencil mark and turn them in with a screwdriver.

lines.text: The anchors come with screws.  I put each one through a 1/2" plastic spacer and turned it down until the spacer could no longer rattle.
lines.text_raw: The anchors come with screws.  I put each one through a 1/2" plastic spacer and turned it down until the spacer could no longer rattle.

lines.text: Clean gloves are a good idea, when handling the finished screen, so as not to get dirt or oil on the surface.
lines.text_raw: Clean gloves are a good idea, when handling the finished screen, so as not to get dirt or oil on the surface.

lines.text: Depending on the size and weight of your finished screen, you may want to get help lifting it.  Be careful!
lines.text_raw: Depending on the size and weight of your finished screen, you may want to get help lifting it.  Be careful!

lines.text: Tilt the top of the screen slightly back over your head and lift it, along the wall, until it is well above the row of anchors.
lines.text_raw: Tilt the top of the screen slightly back over your head and lift it, along the wall, until it is well above the row of anchors.

lines.text: Let the top of the screen fall back against the wall, and slowly lower the screen until the upper frame member catches against the wall anchors.
lines.text_raw: Let the top of the screen fall back against the wall, and slowly lower the screen until the upper frame member catches against the wall anchors.

lines.text: Turn on your projector and, if necessary, refocus the image.
lines.text_raw: Turn on your projector and, if necessary, refocus the image.

lines.text: Adjust the left-right position of the screen, as necessary, to center the image.

lines.text: The projector itself may be aimed up or down to fine-tune the vertical centering.  Many projectors include an "image shift" function for this purpose, as well.
